But that was actually shown in Europe in the late 2000s that the virus completely jumped to another species of biting midge that was not even closely related phylogenetically and it was assumed throughout Europe that none of these vectors were actually um none of these species were actually able to transmit the virus and that testing was all based on just phylogenetic predictions. Um so I think evolutionary history being a component of this can be informative um and in context with ecology too and so I go often go back to what Kim's talking about different data types and how can these data types be joined in some type of predictive model and weighted based on the different systems to lead to a predictive outcome.

utterance: Kezia Manlove: One thing that came up yesterday in the movement discussion was I think this was Mike's observation that like we've got um, you know, really high resolution models for some systems. We've got a kind of global predictions of where spillover should occur through um, kind of through data mining approaches, but we're sort of missing the intermediate scale and I think um, it seems to me like maybe yeah, like I guess what I'm sort of looking for and metabolism maybe seems promising and maybe there's a microbiome component here that's promising as well. It's like how do we refine predictions like a mechanistic based prediction at the intermediate scale that would let us move across species, which I think we're maybe not doing all that well, but still stay grounded in the environment, still be able to make a prediction on the basis of environmental covariance, which I think is eventually maybe what we're going to want to be able to do. Um, but I I'm still struggling to understand how like microbiome there is harder for me like like I I can't tie microbiome as tightly to the environment as I feel I can tie metabolism. Um, so I I totally hear the point that it's going to be pretty salient.
